Course Content 
(See Also the Lecture on Wednesday)
Geological Oceanography
 
Origin/Evolution of Earth,Moon and Ocean, Plate Tectonics and Marine Sediments (Paleo-Oceanography) 
Physical Oceanography
 
Waves,Tides, Surface Ocean Currents, Deep Ocean Currents, 
Conveyor Belt Circulation, El Nino
 


Prelim 1 
Biological Oceanography
 
Primary Production, Food Webs, Microbes, Biologically Carbon Pump, 
Rocky Intertidal, Coral Reefs
, Whales


Chemical Oceanography
 
Sources, Sinks and Cycling of Major Chemical Elements, 
Ocean Acidi
fi
cation and Ocean De-Oxygenation
 


Prelim 2


Climate Change and its Impact on the Ocean Environment
 
Global Warming, Sea Level Rise, Arctic Ice Loss, Extreme Weather 
Other Human Impacts on the Ocean Environment
 
Over
fi
shing, Coastal Pollution
 
A Sustainable Future... 
Final Exam

© 2023 Bruce Monger

nvestigating Oceanography by Sverdrup & Kudela

The new 
Cornell Academic Materials Program (CAMP)
 provides Cornell 
undergraduate students access to all 
required
 academic materials for a single 
fl
at-
rate cost,

 per semester.  The oceanography textbook is listed as 
required
 to 
allow students to access the book without additional cost.  If you are not 
participating in CAMP, you are welcome to consider this textbook as 
optional
.

Save Them by Danson & D’Orso
 
This book is 
Optional
.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Grading...
1.
Two In-Class Prelim Exams (50 questions per exam,
100 points per exam
) 


2.
One Final Exam (100 questions, 
200 points
) 


all exams are multiple choice using bubble sheet answer forms


3.
Weekly Questions (
50 points
 total for semester)


4.
An End of Semester Writing Assignment (
50 points
)


5.
500 Total Possible Points


6.
Grades are computed from percent correct score out of 500 possible points
80.00 to 83.33 =  B-
90.00 to 93.33 =  A-
83.34 to 86.66 =  B
93.34 to 96.66 =  A
86.67 to 89.99 =  B+
96.67 to 99.99 =  A+
Example...

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Early and Late Prelim Exams...
1.
It is possible to take the 
original multiple-choice prelim exam
 on the Friday 
before
 
the 
regularly scheduled Monday exam if arrangements are made at least 
one week prior
 to the 
exam day 
and
 if the excuse for missing the regular exam is a good one.  
 
•
Typical valid reasons for taking an early exam are: participation a Cornell athletic event, job 
interview, religious holiday observance.
 
2.
The possibility of taking a make-up exam
 
after
 
the original exam has been given will be much 
more restricted.  In almost all cases a makeup is restricted to family or medical emergencies.  
 
•
You will need to obtain some sort of documentation supporting the reason for missing the 
exam - e.g., An email from your college’s Student Services or Advising Center. 
 
•
M
ake-up exams will likely contain a mix of multiple-choice 
and
 some written-short-answer 
questions.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Final Exam Schedule...
1.
With the very narrow exception of a family or medical emergency, everyone 
will have to take the 
fi
nal exam on the scheduled exam date.
 
2.
Because this class is so large, I cannot allow anyone to take an early 
fi
nal 
exam because 
to allow 
one
 would require me to allow 
all
 who ask
 and I 
cannot secure a room large enough during the early part of the 
fi
nals period 
to accommodate all who would ask for an early exam.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Weekly Question
1.
Give you an opportunity to express
 
some 
personal thoughts and/or feelings
 
about a topic 
that was brought up in class during the week.
 
2.
It is also meant to 
keep you connected to the class on a weekly basis
 and in so doing 
encourage regular class attendance.
See class Canvas docs for full details
The Purpose... 
Most questions are meant to focus your attention on the following 5 basic ideas:
1.
Humanity is 
not
 the center of the universe.
 
2.
The ocean is an import part of Earth's Overall Life Support System.
 
3.
The time-frames of global-scale threats are
 
extremely short (i.e., 20 years).
 
4.
You have a civic duty to
 
raise your voice and ask government leaders to lead. 
 
5.
Moving toward a more sustainable world should be seen as running 
toward
 a much better 
world.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
1.
The weekly question is not meant to be “a test”.
  It is intended to make you stop and ask yourself a 
personal question and to give 
your own thoughts/opinion/perspective
.
 
2.
There is no right or wrong answer.  If you meet the minimum word requirement you will get full credit (5 
points) for the question.
 
3.
There will be 10 questions over the course of the semester so you can earn up the 50 points by 
answering all of the questions on time.  
 
There is a strict deadline for submitting your answer. The only exception would be for a 
documented medical or family emergency 
Each student is allowed one free pass on a  question and given full credit.  Please use this wisely.
 
Note: there are 500 total points possible for the class; so
 
the weekly questions have the 
potential to change your 
fi
nal class grade by one full letter!!! 
So, please be careful.
 
4.
The TA reading your answers will add one additional extra credit point to the top 10% of responses that 
they deem to be exceptionally insightful.
Grading the Weekly Question... 
See class Canvas docs for full details

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Letter to Congress Assignment (Worth 50 Points)
1.
To give you an opportunity to get off the soul-crushing academic treadmill of exam taking and term 
paper writing and, instead, provide a moment for you to gather together some of 
your own 
personal thoughts and feelings about an environmental issue brought up in the class.
 
2.
To give you a sense of 
ownership of what you have learned in this class
 
and make you “see” 
that the course material has some application to your life. 
 
3.
To promote a strong sense of 
Civic Duty
 for you to raise your voice.
 
4.
To maybe even change the world!
Purpose...
See class Canvas for full details...


1.
Your letter can be Pro or Con on Environmental Conservation
 
2.
Length:  About Two Pages Single Spaced
 
3.
Deadline: 
Last Day of Instruction

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Student Disability Accommodation
If you have a student disability requiring a special accommodation that has 
been cleared through the Student Disabilities Office, you should reach out 
to the 
SDS Coordinator
 (
Alejandro Tejera, alt74@cornell.edu
) to confirm 
your accommodation. 
 
Exams needing special accommodation will be administered via the 
Alternate Testing Program run my the Student Disabilities Office.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Academic Integrity
1.
The single main purpose of the class is devoted to the idea of living 
with integrity as engaged citizens of the world. 
2.
The goal of the course is to have you take what you learn in this class and act 
to make a better word by 1) raising your voice/opinion and demanding 
government leaders work for positive change and 2) by making positive 
changes in your daily life.
 
3.
Academic integrity violations are in direct opposition to this important message, 
and therefore integrity violations will result in a failing grade for this class.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Challenges of Large Classes...
1.
Talking During Class
 
2.
Class Attendance

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Talking During Class...
1.
Bailey Hall can give students a feeling of being at a fun social event where open-ended 
conversations with friends seems totally appropriate.  I am certain that placing the same 
students in a smaller classroom would generate a totally different outcome  - 
so it’s the 
nature of the large room and not the nature of the students
.
 
2.
I honestly don’t like telling anyone to be quiet, but I am responsible to others in the class to 
provide the best possible learning experience.  
So, I have made a promise to myself to get 
past my social discomfort of telling someone to be quiet and I will periodically ask all of 
you to quiet down...
 
 
Please know it’s not about me, but rather about my concern for 
everyone else in the class! 
 
3.
And please write to me and let me know if I am letting things slip and the talking levels have 
started to climb! 
I think by working as a group we can make Bailey Hall a great experience
!

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Attendance in Large Classes...
Your chance for a good grade is de
fi
nitely 
improved by coming to class...


If you 
do
 come to class 
you will likely get an 
A-
 
If you 
do not
 come to class, and just study the 
slides before an exam, 
you will likely get a 
C+
 
If you 
do
 come to class, 
and
 you do put in a decent 
effort studying, you have a 
very good chance
 of 
getting an 
A+
  
 
If you 
do not
 come to class 
it is essentially 
impossible to get an 
A
 
in this class no matter how 
hard you study (see the graph for proof)

© 2023 Bruce Monger
The recorded lectures are a nice way to makeup a missed lecturer and a nice 
way to review some of the material you are not totally clear on, 
but they are 
not
 
a great substitute for being in class!
 
The music at the start of lecture is meant to be upbeat and get you jazzed-up 
about learning the material -  
the energy of Bailey Hall is way more fun than 
sitting in front of a small screen on a laptop in your dark dorm room — and 
because of this, you’ll learn more of the material and do better on the exams if 
you come to class.
 
My Promise —
 
If you promise to come to class, I promise that I will put as much 
energy as possible into keeping you fully entertained/engaged!
All of the Lectures are Video Recorded and 
Posted on Canvas...

© 2023 Bruce Monger
1.
For the longest time I 
fi
gured you were all adults and if you chose not to come to class it 
was basically your own choice and it would only hurt you and nobody else.
 
2.
But I have “evolved” my thinking on the attendance issue...
 
It is my job to see that you get the best possible grade in this class
 — because it 
means I have taught you well!
 
more importantly,
 there is a very big difference in what is learned by just memorizing 
facts and numbers from Powerpoint slides 
versus
 listening to me speak passionately 
about the problems we all face and the way forward to a better world.
 
 
3.
This class is meant to be 
much-much more than mindlessly memorizing a bunch of 
numbers
 to put down on a silly bubble sheet! 
 
4.
If you don’t come to class you might get a decent enough grade, but 
you’ll miss out on 
the chance of experiencing a big change in the way you see the world...
Why Am I Pushing the Attendance Thing?

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Public Service Announcement Slides Displayed In Class...
1.
I get a large number of requests from students throughout the semester who want to advertise 
amazingly good causes...
 
2.
In an attempt to keep the number of slides presented before class to a minimum I limit permissible slides 
to 
just two broad categories
:
 
 
announcements for 
events, or for student organizations, that deal with...
 
 
ocean/environmental research
 
climate change
 
sustainable future
 
voter registration
  
announcements for a 
very speci
fi
c 
one-time fund-raising event
 on campus 
 
for a socially good cause...
 
 
 
 
3.
Slides presented in class will also be posted on the Canvas course site under 
“Public Service 
Announcements”
 so you can pick up the relevant details later...

© 2023 Bruce Monger
And Speaking of Announcements...

© 2023 Bruce Monger
No Labs This Week

© 2023 Bruce Monger
1.
Bailey Hall is a very special place
 
2.
It underwent a $17 million renovation in 2006
 
3.
It has been added to the National Register of Historic Places
 
4.
The folks who take care of Bailey are amazingly nice people who 
work with a bright and sincere sense of enthusiasm to maintain 
Bailey Hall’s pristine condition.  
 
5.
So please be nice and don’t bring food into Bailey!
 
Food and Drinks are 
Not
 Allowed in Bailey Hall
